title: Woody Bay Walking Route

images.title: Trevor Rickard / North Devon coast at Woody Bay
images.caption: North Devon coast at Woody Bay. In the foreground Martinhoe Manor sits in a clearing in the woods. In the background are The Valley of the Rocks and Foreland Point.

images.title: Martin Southwood / Remains of old pier at Woody Bay
images.caption: Remains of old pier at Woody Bay. Built in 1895 by the owner of Martinhoe Manor, Col. Benjamin Lake, it only survived until damaged by heavy storms in 1900 and was demolished in 1902.

images.title: Philip Halling / South West Coast Path near Martinhoe
images.caption: South West Coast Path near Martinhoe

images.title: Hassan from Oxford, UK, CC BY 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Waterfall near the bay.

images.title: Martin Southwood / Woody Bay cottages, approach path and lime kilns
images.caption: Woody Bay cottages, approach path and lime kilns. A "road" descends as far as the cottages but then it's a steep path to the beach.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Woodland above Woody Bay
images.caption: Woodland above Woody Bay. With excellent views east along the coast.

images.title: Philip Halling / South West Coast Path above Woody Bay
images.caption: South West Coast Path above Woody Bay

images.title: Derek Harper / Woodrush on field boundary near Woody Bay
images.caption: Woodrush on field boundary near Woody Bay. There must be a wall under there somewhere. This straight boundary, covered with a species of woodrush (Luzula sp) drops away at a narrow angle from the coast path; West Woodybay Wood is on the other side of it.

description: Explore this peaceful wooded cove and enjoy waterfalls, woodland trails and splendid views of the Bristol Channel. Woody Bay is located on the coast of the Exmoor National Park. The Hanging Water stream runs through the woodland with lovely waterfalls and interesting flora and fauna to enjoy. This walk starts at the car park on Sir Robert's Path and takes you through the woodland to the pretty little bay with its secluded pebble beach. If you would like to extend your walking in the area then you could head west along the coast to the lovely Heddon Valley. Here you will find riverside walking trails and the imposing cliffs of Heddon's Mouth. You could also start the walk from here as shown in the video below. If you head east then you will come to the spectacular Valley of the Rocks where there are a number of interesting geological features to see.
